subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Pronunciation resource
msgSnippet: It looks fine to me. Here are three relevant entries: abaculus /@/ b/&/k/j//@/l/@/s abacus /&/b/@/k/@/s crash kr/&//S/ I think you just read the wrong line
messageBody:
It looks fine to me. Here are three relevant entries:

abaculus /@/'b/&/k/j//@/l/@/s
abacus '/&/b/@/k/@/s
crash kr/&//S/

I think you just read the wrong line for 'abacus'. I can't see where
you got 'crashaclurbeler'.

Ted

On Dec 5, 2007 7:30 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> tinyallen scripsit:
>
> > Those who are interested in how to pronounce English words should
> > take a look at the Moby Lists.
> >
> > http://www.dcs.shef.ac.uk/research/ilash/Moby/
>
> Unfortunately, the Pronunciatior file unpacks improperly, and all the
> data is badly garbled. For example, the first word that isn't a name is
> "abacus", which is given the pronunciation "abakjylys" (in QS-SAMPA),
> something like "abaculous" in TO. And all the other words are equally
> useless: "crash" is pronounced as if it were "crashaclurbeler".
>
>
> > I would like to know what dialect the Pronunciator wordlist is
> > written in.
>
> Judging by the pronunciation key supplied, it's the same "General American"
> dialect as the CMU dictionary, which indeed is supplied along with it:
> TRAP = BATH, CLOTH = THOUGHT, NORTH = FORCE.
>
> --
> That you can cover for the plentiful John Cowan
> and often gaping errors, misconstruals, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
> and disinformation in your posts cowan@...
> through sheer volume -- that is another
> misconception. --Mike to Peter
>
